title: Urgot's itemization is horrendously limited
body:
to the point where his only real AD item that can be called core is {{item:3071}} and he is effectively disbarred from any other juggernaut items. Can't buy Sterak's, or Titanic, and Triforce is obviously out of the question because of how his kit works. Attack speed items are not good because he actually loses DPS by buying them if he ever uses W. {{item:3022}} is situationally strong but not worth purchasing every game, same for {{item:3812}}. His rune options are pretty mediocre between Aftershock, Comet, and Spellbook, but that's a different problem. 

If Urgot wants to itemize more offensively than Cleaver-fulltank, then he has to dip into other classes' items, a problem that existed for fighters a long time ago and was the reason we got items like Sterak's in the first place. Namely assassin items, Ghostblade and Duskblade (there's actually a Korean Urgot buying both of these and doing really well in high elo)

I'd like to be able to build my juggernaut like he's a juggernaut, though, and not an assassin. thx

replies.body:
Yeah. Feels pretty bad. Not getting full effect from Conqueror has a similar feel.

On the plus side, we've been testing a few new fighter items that hopefully don't need to have the 'melee only' flag on them, but it's hard to say if they'll make it to Live in that state.

Recently I put in a change for testing where Urgot was just considered melee for the purposes of systems like these, but overwhelmingly got negative feedback on that.

My personal preference would be that we have another split similar to how we have range / melee that describes defensive profile rather than range profile. In most cases they line up, but if for example, we had a light / heavy split, that might do good stuff for making champions like Urgot and GP more balanceable within the item system. Biggest immediate problem I can see with that, however, is that there's no immediate gameplay connection to that profile in the same way there is for AA ranges.

If by "overwhelming negative feedback" you mean Maple Syrup, I suggest you at least release it to the PBE announcing it is experimental and have the community as a whole decide whether it is good or not. I've said this before but for some champions like urgot it just makes sense to be "melee"
I get that, and I don't want to get into who said what since that's not a very good path for me to head down, but it wasn't Maple. I could convince Maple most things are a good idea :p

I'm just curious, what was the negative feedback with him being considered melee? Too much damage? Items/Runes too strong?

Also, I've seen rioters say that attack speed scaling on W has been tested, what went wrong with that? If it can't crit, I can't imagine that being too strong.

It was actually more a matter of principle wherein if we broke ranged/melee expectations for champions, what's the point of the distinction and what kind of can of worms is being opened up insofar as power creep and intuitiveness of the game are concerned.

"Unique passive, urgot is a ranged melee champion"

:thinking:

We already have alot of things like no boots, Mana Mage, Velkoz blink autos that aren't "really ranged" and etc...
Vel's autos, like thresh and kayle, aren't particles so they aren't blocked by windwall.

Still a ranged aa that isn't a projectile that "breaks the mold"

There are alot of things that break molds. There isn't much reason why Urgot couldn't be a one off, except that someone somewhere decided that "That wouldn't be ok" even though you could list something that breaks the mold on alot of champions.
I'm not sure you're allowed to mention power creep. That's a whole storage house full of worms, discussion-wise.

The roster is already so large that a few rules breaks should be considered fine, IMO. Just as the golden rule of MtG exists so that you can break rules for more interesting and balanced gameplay on a card-by-card basis, League design should be fine with breaking some rules for more interesting or balanced gameplay on a kit-by-kit and champion-by-champion basis. 

I remember someone else suggesting part of his passive give him access to Urgot-only versions of Sterak's and other important items, which made a lot of sense; if other champions can have unique ways of interacting with the shop, like GP's Silver Serpents or Viktor's hex core, I don't see why Urgot can't have a special version of Sterak's and other useful items. And I also don't really see why he can't be classed as melee either; I  don't see how this is less intuitive than, say, how building attack speed on Jhin just doesn't give you attack speed, or how dual-form champions interact with ranged/melee splits. 

At the end of the day, League has so many champions that the game is going to struggle to be both intuitive and balanced in certain designspaces that it chooses to explore. At that point -- **especially since League has such a burden of knowledge to play competently anyways** -- I don't think there's any real sin in breaking a "rule" here and there to help game balance.

I mean there is already "weird" scenarios with things like Rakan. Rakan HAS an auto attack animation for punching and the rest of his animations are him slapping things with his cape. Nothing in his play SEEMS ranged, but he is labeled as one because aa range reasons. Thresh at least has an AA range of 450 so it at least FEELS more like a ranged champion, but Rakan at a clean 300 is very short. Even Irelia is rocking 200 which is quite large and doesn't FEEL that much shorter than someone like Rakan.

you shouldn't care about inconsistencies between melee/ranged. Currently you're making Jhin stack additively with dragon and guinsoo while the others stack multiplicatively/recursively. I'm sure you can make other exceptions (urgot)

As far as not breaking the rules goes, ye could give him 150 AA, then add an additional effect to his passive giving him an additional 150 range to end up at 300.

I mean, AAtrox AA's from range and doesn't behave like it when he uses his massacre (Tiamat etc still works just fine), so it'd be within the rules, right?

I'd honestly assume a mix of both. He would be getting all the benefits of melee items while still having more range than most of them. Plus there would be quite a few nightmarish items to build on urgot. {{item:3748}} comes immediately to mind; he would have pretty insane area damage with it. Sterak's on Urgot would also be incredibly good on him, since he has a total AD ratio on quite literally everything. Plus, things like conqueror and grasp would be really hard to deal with when fighting him (if you're purely melee; he outranges you while maintaining conqueror through his W, or he would constantly be getting full grasp procs on you while you can't retaliate without going in on him.)

Regarding {{item:3053}}...

We're not talking about giving free buffs, but **giving him back what he used to build**.

Sterak's Gage was good on Urgot and not on a matter of damages, but survival.

> Plus, things like conqueror and grasp would be really hard to deal with when fighting him (if you're purely melee; he outranges you while maintaining conqueror through his W, or he would constantly be getting full grasp procs on you while you can't retaliate without going in on him.)

That's exactly what happens when you go under whoever other champ that is abusing Conqueror, I don't see how it would be a Urgot's only related problem.

Regarding the Sterak, yes, it might not be an issue, but making Urgot a melee champion would give him access to other items that might be problematic (the hydras, for example, giving him quite a bit of waveclear past his passive procs). 

As for the other champs abusing conqueror, they do at least get into true melee range, for the most part. Sure, they might hurt and nuke you and all, but in laning phase you at least can fight back if they try to go in for it; melee vs urgot you may not have such a luxury. That extra 200 some range that urgot has over another melee could put him into essentially the position of Gnar; except he has the constant power of mega Gnar to boot.

Of course, this is all raw theory; there isn't a way to prove it without actually putting it into practice.

> Why not consider him melee

There has to be a better way to balance or buff urgot than just straight up making him [pseudo] melee, because he is and always was distinctly ranged, despite being a bruiser that wants to use the rune. I think either new items or other major keystones, or a more specified change in mind would be better suited. Even if that was in the way of more armor pen (in a similar vein to Darius) to compete with the fact that he cannot use conqueror.

I would take light/heavy over ranged/melee any day for non-auto based items. 

When comparing the two, range has a gameplay connection but there's no set number or characteristic for when 'ranged' ends and 'melee' begins, with auto attack range enhancement and non projectile ranged autos (like why is kayle with righteous fury ranged while aatrox with blood massacre isn't when both of them go above Urgot's range?). 'heaviness' has no gameplay connection but is visible in how the champion simply looks, and makes balance easier.

Just put in brackets (Heavy) or (Light) and highlight the stats in the shop, and add a small icon or something next to range or while pressing C.

OR if you want to preserve build-per-champion-diversity and not introduce a new stat, you can simply separate the two set of items completely. Passive: Heavy - You cannot buy light items.
This will even help with abyssal mask + lost chapter building mages. (Make abyssal mask 'heavy', lost chapter 'light'). Items that are neutral like Botrk are neither, but clearly marksmen items like Rapid Fire Cannon, Runaan's hurricane, and IE should never, ever, be bought with sterak's gage. Most champions that can do this are TERRIBLE to play vs. when it's their meta build (like Yi, Rengar and Trynd in a crit-bruiser meta. That simply shouldn't be allowed. Pick one, and balance it like hybrid AP AD champs like kaisa are balanced. With two distinct builds)

Though imo if marksmen weren't so capable of synergizing with literally any AD item that wasn't restricted none of this would be a problem.

Your solution isn't fixing the problem, though.
There might be broader use cases between "heavy" and "light" but who would classify as who? Those are not intuitive tags because they aren't relevant to gameplay. "Melee" VS "ranged" is more specific even if you don't know exact number of units where one AA range ends and the other begins. Champions that fire projectiles are usually ranged while melee don't do that. You can also judge that by how close the targets you aim at, need to be to you. There are exceptions, of course but those are few and far between (you already mentioned Kayle and Aatrox).

Switching to "heavy" and "light" would carry over the exact same problems as "ranged" and "melee". We're just using two different words to describe another way to classify items.

>Switching to "heavy" and "light" would carry over the exact same problems as "ranged" and "melee". We're just using two different words to describe another way to classify items.

It wouldn't, the problem isn't on clarity, it's on balance. Arbitrarily assigning items to champions based on a stat that otherwise has nothing to do with them is a problem (runaan's and tiamat will be excluded from this separation and will still be ranged-melee because they actually have to do with autos), assigning items to champions based on their intended items actually fixes balance problems with creating ranged champions who act like classes that *tend* to be melee.
Have you tought about making items *scale* with range? The higher the range, the lesser the benefit. Feels like a nice organic way of balancing items, but it probably requires a lot of work.

If new items that he can use are in the works, great, but that always scares me. Just thinking back to "you can never kill me" GP like you referenced form the start of the season made me seriously considering dropping league, and I did till he got nerfed(still more needed in my opinion) and Conqueror came out. If Rakan and Thresh can be considered ranged, I don't see why Urgot cant be melee, for balance purposes.

The only Items I can find that this would affect are as follows:
- Phage = Movement speed is no longer halfed, so Urgot's mobility is helped slightly.
- Tiamat = good early buy if you want to hard push, but wouldn't be bought early over Phage most likely.
- Titanic Hydra = Since the W reduces on-hit, the proc wouldn't help massively, but would offer him a really nice spike like other Juggs such as Darius that build it when ahead for wave clear and balance defensive/offensive stats with emphasis on his "AOE destruction" identity.
- Frozen Mallet = This would be a massive buff to his stickiness, but even when the slow was 30% for him he was never broken, so I don't think this would result in massive power spike overall.
- Dead Man's Plate = I could see this become staple considering some Urgot's build this now, but with Frozen Mallet it would probably just become "either or" decision on what you need at that time.
- Sterak's Gage = This is the big one. Access to this Item would be exactly what Urgot need to do what he want to do a Juggernaut, and could be the biggest reason nerf might be needed in some areas of his kit if it went through.

Ketstones:
- Fleet Footwork = Would remove the heal reduction which is super nice, but doubt anyone would take this. Even though lane sustain is always nice to have, especially if in a rough match up, Grasp would better probably.
- Conqueror = THE Bruiser keystone, and would be so nice to have access to as Urgot. This also could demand nerfs in some other areas of the base kit.
- Grasp of the Undying = Would remove the damage and healing reduction, allowing this to be a great option for the lanes you might need to sutain out, but most likely wouldn't be taken over Conqueror or PTA.
- Glacial Augment = Could also be an option if you don't want to get Frozen Mallet or Dead Man's, but prob wouldn't be to much better then it is now.
